[PCORI, NIH Announce Plans For $30 Million Study On Falls](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/pcori-nih-announce-plans-for-30-million-study-on-falls/) The nation's largest and most intensive study of how to best prevent seniors' injuries from falling will begin next year under a $30 million grant announced Wednesday by the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute and the National Institutes of Health. [](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/alternative-medicine-boosted-from-health-law-on-paper/) [Health Law Boosts Status Of Alternative Medicine — At Least On Paper](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/alternative-medicine-boosted-from-health-law-on-paper/) The Affordable Care Act says that insurance companies "shall not discriminate" against any state-licensed health provider, which could lead to better coverage of chiropractic, homeopathic and naturopathic care. Alternative medicine is also mentioned in parts of the law on wellness, prevention and research. [](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/stateline-health-care-cuts-vaccinations-research-sequester/) [Health Care Cuts From Vaccinations To Research](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/stateline-health-care-cuts-vaccinations-research-sequester/) Sequestration's cuts will likely affect how low-income Americans get maternal care, vaccinate their children and get treatment for mental illness, even if the cuts largely spare Medicare and Medicaid. Some doctors and patients are pushing to change that. [](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/portland-fluoride-debate/) [The Great Fluoride Debate In Portland](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/portland-fluoride-debate/) Portland, Ore., is the largest American city that doesn't add fluoride to its drinking water. Activists have been vocal, for and against a proposal to change that. The science shows that fears of side effects from small amounts of fluoride to protect teeth are unfounded. [Prevention: The Answer To Curbing Chronically High Health Care Costs (Guest Opinion)](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/052411thorpelever/) Kenneth Thorpe and Jonathan Lever write that Congress should be working to reduce health care costs by reducing the rates of the chronic diseases. Their message: It takes investment in the ounce of prevention to realize the pound of cure.
